segments.text: arm of Boyd Page at that time.
He was right across from the president's office in Coke.
In Coke.
Now, did you, was there a dean of the college appointed then, or did you?
No.
As I probably kind of caustically said in this thing I wrote up, Rutter had me doing two and three jobs for the price of one all through my tenure under it.
No, he, I was
I didn't even have the title of acting dean.
I was the dean of the college.
I was running A&M for him.
Because when I first knew who you were, you were vice president for academic affairs and?
Dean of the graduate college, yeah.
But that came later.
I never, in fact, I was trying to talk him into hiring somebody to direct and coordinate research, and he said, okay, Hall, add that to your title.
And in those days, generally summarize what your responsibilities were.
My responsibility was to do anything that Earl Rudder asked me to do, and he expected me to run the academic ship, and that was it, which included student relations.
In the early days, we didn't have a dean of students until Hannigan was hired to replace him, to replace Benny Zinn, that had been dean of students.
There were four school deans then?
Well, I can name one.
There were agriculture, arts and sciences, engineering, veterinary medicine, and education came later after Rutter was president.
So there were four.
And when I get here in 59, Frank Hubert had just been hired.
To be dean.
And Benson was.
Dean of engineering.
Gus Watkins, and Al Price.
Al Price was veterinary medicine.
Let's see.
Am I leaving out something?
No, those are the four.
No, that was it, because I immediately talked Rutter into reorganizing the whole campus, and that's when we established the new colleges, like science and geoscience and et cetera.
In fact, they're all there now.
What was a routine week for you?
and the way Mr.
Rudder related to you and the other key administrators.
Did you all have a weekly administrators staff meeting?
No, we didn't have any formal staff meetings, but in the early days right after he came,
He would call, have a meeting with Dorsey and me every evening after the others had gone home.
We'd stay there until we had hashed out whatever he wanted done.
Sometimes it would run to 9 to 9.30 at night, even though many of us had never eaten lunch that day.
No, he was a hard worker himself.
In the early days, he would be there early in the morning and stay there late at night, except when he was out of town on business, university or other business.
Was he a good listener?
I would say he was, yeah.
He would listen to people he trusted, I'll put it that way.
And I'm not going to ask the negative on this one.
Who were those you think he trusted most?
Well, in the early days, only two people, Dorsey McCrory and myself.
He didn't trust the Deans.
He wanted me to interact with them and get the things done, which I did, of course.
And he didn't react pleasantly to someone that tried to go around the chain of command, did he?
No, sir.
Everything was formal with him.
You had to have appointments, and you didn't meet around the bush with him at all.
Where as you first began to settle into that task, were there some immediate problems that you felt you had to deal with?
Well, the main thing was trying to get the existing organization schools and so forth on a better basis, which we did, and start hiring and assisting.
We hire better faculty, particularly those for the research vent, which I insisted upon, Mr.
Rudder endorsed.
Essentially, the only research that was taking place in the early days was in agriculture.
Even engineering wasn't conducting any research to mount anything.

I convinced Mr. Rutter that we should model the entire research effort after agriculture with joint appointments, teaching and research, even in arts and sciences, although that was the last one to follow that route.
The appointment of Frank Hubert was important to me.
He had been my seventh grade band director and my 12th grade principal.
Yeah.
How did he get identified to be the new dean of arts and sciences?
This way.
He was a well-known college, I mean, high school superintendent.
I believe he was at Beaumont when he was hired.
Orange.
Orange, you're right.
Yeah, Orange.
You're right.
Yeah, that's right.
He was hired primarily because he was a well-known educator.
And he knew Earl Rudder.
That's another reason.
I think they had overlapped in Austin.
Was that it?
Because Hubert had been the number two man in the State Department of Education before going back to Orange.
Oh, you're right.
You're right.
And I think.
Yeah.
Did you identify him, or did Rutter, or do you remember?
No, I had nothing to do with the initial appointment of Frank Herbert.
Rutter handled it entirely.
And I endorsed it.
I did convince him to establish a college of education school initially and to let Hubert decide whether we wanted to be dean of arts and sciences or of education.
And initially he took arts and sciences, but later when we split it off to education, he took that helm.
Staying with Mr. Rutter, normally he was...
there on campus all day, five days a week?
When he wasn't involved in some other activity, yeah.
That was in the early days.
Later, I hesitate to say this, but his health deteriorated badly and most people weren't aware of this.
No, I was not aware of that.
He was absent a lot from the office.
And about three or four years after he was president, he spent over a month over at the O'Brien Hospital.
And I used to go over there every morning and spend an hour or so discussing everything and getting his blessing on actions that needed.
What were his key concerns as a decision maker?
Did he have any pet peeves and pet joys?
Well, he liked action.
He didn't like people that would dilly-dally around and not just bring something to fruition.
And he wanted it done in a hurry.
And I presume he probably didn't like theory as much as he liked reality.
No, he liked practicality, yes.
He wasn't adverse to theory as long as it tied into the objective that we... Now, by 1962, A&M was blessed by his friendship with John Connolly.
And I presume that we were helped in Austin by that relationship?
Oh, yeah, very much so.
Connolly was a strong supporter of A&M behind the scenes, even though he was a UT graduate.
But, I mean, he was behind the scenes.
He was supporting A&M.
Oh, yeah, he and Rutter were great friends.
Probably you may remember in the book I mentioned that the surprise meeting, we were coming back from Junction.
He didn't tell me until we were
Leaving his place, his ranch, we stopped at his ranch on the way back.
And he said, we got a meeting I got to attend.
And we stopped at Waco.
To my surprise, the people he was meeting was John Connolly and LBJ and their staff.
I said, Mr. Rutter, maybe I better just stay at the bar or go get something to eat or do something.
He said, no, you come in there.
He said, get you something to eat.
Keep your damn mouth shut.
Just listen.
That's what I did.
Now, did Mr. Rutter have a good sense of humor?
Yeah, surprisingly he did.
He didn't display it too often, but he did.
And let's see, food.
Did he have special foods he enjoyed?
Well, I don't know if you can call that a typical Texan, but he liked the fiery Mexican foods.
In fact, even though he had stomach ulcers, he used to get on me because, Mr. Rutter, why in the hell do you eat that fiery stuff?
It's burning your stomach up.
He said,
Little hot stuff good for you.
One of the key things that I hope you can recall for me is the Aspirations Report and all of those studies.
Do you know who came up with the idea that we have a study of what A&M might become in 1976?
Well, I'd like to take credit for it, although I'm sure there's a number of different inputs.
The Association of Former Students claim that they had a strong influence, and I guess they did have some effect.
I convinced Mr. Rutter we were supposed to do the Southern Association accreditation in the coming year.
I said, Mr. Rutter, as long as we're doing this, and Dorsey and I had talked it over with Rutter at great length, why don't we do our own study, what we want to become?

because we got to do all most of this anyway for the self-study and we got the people appointed and so forth we'll just select a few and do it and we did now uh as you recall i became the secretary of the aspirations committee and we met for many months and i think most of us on that committee were dumbfounded on the day that we voted unanimously for all of those
tradition-shattering changes.

uh were you and mr rutter and other key administrators surprised when our committee turned in the report at the recommendations i wasn't i think mr rutter was initially in fact a certain part of it he wasn't going to endorse at all until i convinced him that he would be in the best interest to do it all right as i remember the conversation with you one day you gave me

uh... one of the first draft copies which mister rudder had annotated questions so forth and you ask me to review it redrafted bring in and uh... i went back and said to you and said that he in the number of instances was questioning the committee's subjective judgment and that we really believed it and that therefore couldn't undo that and uh... as i recall you said i'll state my job
on the committee's right to, all right, what was Mr. Rutter's reaction when the final report wasn't changed?
Well, initially he was opposed to certain parts of it, but it took Dorsey McCrory and myself several months to convince him that we should go ahead with it.
I think some of the outside influences also impinged on Mr. Rutter's decision.
As I have looked at it, I thought we had Bill Moore for it.
Bill Moore was one that was endorsing it and telling him he would push it in the legislature.
John Connolly, behind the scenes, was doing it.
And the Washington LBJ.
Ed Cooper told me in the interview with him
But in retrospect, he believed that there had been a conversation at the White House when LBJ told him you've got to do it.
There was.
The former representative from here.
Teague.
Yeah.
He and Rutter were cut from the same cloth.
Oh, yes, yes.
I shouldn't tell you this, but when he used to come down here to visit, Rutter would invite me over to the president's house and over drinks.
He would ask me to key him in on several things that he and I wanted to do and we had underway and so forth.
And they would kid each other.
You'd think they hated each other's guts to hear them talk, but that really wasn't the case.
They were blood brothers.
And then Jake Pickle, the Austin representative, went way back.
I don't know much about Pickle's influence.
I think it came later in the game.
But they were old, positive friends.
Now, you need to leave when?
No, no, not right now.
I've got a bad case of kidneys.
I've got to go.
Oh, all right, unplug.
Oh, that's right.
As long as we were talking, is it on now?
Yes.
Talking about Earl Rudder, I'd like to make a few comments.
Most people on the campus were scared to death of Earl Rudder.
In some cases, they had good reasons for it.
But the reason he and I got along and he knew from the start that I wasn't afraid of him a bit.
I would stand up to him and talk to him, and he respected me for it.
And we got along very well as a result.
And he never did...
Well, he got angry a couple times with me, but he never did really blast me like I've seen him blast some of the faculty and other deans and so forth.
And the result, a lot of them hated his guts, just to be blunt about it.
Now, I heard through the grapevine that he had a high respect for Fred Benson.
Is that?
He did, and I did, too.
Fred and I got along about as well as any of the deans.
Al Price was an excellent dean, too.
Al was sort of quiet and unassuming, but he got the job done.
Because I heard a version of his one day fussing at the deans.
maybe that's too weak a word, about that aspirations report and that Benson said, Mr. President, you ask them for their recommendations.
If you didn't want to hear what they had to recommend, you shouldn't ask them.
He's entirely correct.
Fred wasn't afraid of Mr. Rutter either.
That's the reason that Earl and Fred got along well, too.
Because you never show any fear of Mr. Rutter because he'd be right on you.
Of those changes...
non-compulsory core, co-education, was Mr. Rutter more concerned about one of those than the other?
Initially, he was opposed to all three.
The least was changing the name of college to university.
But even that, it took us a long time of argument with him to get him convinced about it.
The last I think that he capitulated on was women.
But he gave in.
And with all of these important people being supportive, one day in 1970, not long before he went to the hospital, I was over there begging for money for the library.

And I got him to smile because I said, Mr. Rutter, they couldn't say you weren't a Texan, you weren't an Aggie, you hadn't served the country, that you were one of these fuddy-duddy PhDs that were just here passing through.
And he grinned and he said, oh, I never thought of any of that.
And I said, oh, I'm sure you didn't.
Yeah, well.
No, he and I, and Dorsey, and not always, sometimes just the two of us, would hassle these things out at great length.
It took me a long time to convince him that this was for the good of A&M.
He told me also in that same session in 1970, he said, if your committee had recommended the name that LSU has,
It would have gotten through.
And I said, what do you mean?
And he said, the official name of the school in Baton Rouge is Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College.
That's true.
Still is.
And he said, that way, us old-timers could have called ourselves Aggies and talked about A&M.
And he said, then you young kids could have talked about Texas State.
I now see his point very clearly.

uh it was it was a surprise to me uh then yeah he did argue for that he didn't like a and m he says you're going to put periods after a and after him i said no it's just carrying over the old tradition of the agricultural mechanical without spelling it out just saying it's the a and m
Texas A&M University.
It took him a long time.
Yeah, he did bring up about LSU's name.
Now the board members, I know you mentioned some of them a while ago during that era.
Sterling Evans and Boydle and I presume Al Davies and...
Oh, the former Southwestern Bell president.
The board came along with it?
No, not all of the old Aggies that were on the board were in favor of it, but they finally
went with it because they had political pressure from other places put on, too.
And I know the former students, John Lindsay and- John Lindsay was-
He wasn't on the board at that time, but he came on the board later.
He was president of the former students when they endorsed him.
You're right.
I remember that now.
I'm trying to think.
Jimmy Aston from Dallas was in that era.
Oh, there's a couple of others.
In the 60s, did you feel we were making progress?
Yeah, we were making great progress academically.
I thought so.
Oh, yeah.
I thought we were making better progress than we were in some of the administrative areas.
No, I thought we made great progress.
In fact, I think it set the real solid foundation for what happened under your friend and mine, Jack, later.
Let's go on.
You said, Mr. Rutter, you were aware of his declining health because you saw him regularly and so forth.
Were there times that, in fact, you and others
had to make decisions and then relay the action to Mr. Rutter?
Not too often, only it would be a rare occasion.
I usually check with Mr. Rutter about any major decision because I knew the way that he reacted.
Now, let's see.
He brought in Dean of Students... Hannigan.
Hannigan.
Yeah, Jim Hannigan.
And he came about not long after you became the Chief Academic Officer.
Yeah, he was the...
Well, after Benny Zinn, the things just sort of, student relations just sort of vacillated.
In fact, Mr. Rutter handled a lot of the student relations himself in the early days.
He delighted doing that more than making major decisions.
Wouldn't he have enjoyed being the commandant of the Corps?
Oh, yeah.
He would have enjoyed that thoroughly.
Now, I have the impression that Mr. Rutter worked a lot,
long hours, but almost never took any of his frustrations and joys home.
No, and you can confirm this with Margaret if you ever talk with her.
Margaret knew less about what was going on at A&M than almost any of the wives because he never took, he would not discuss business at the university or college in the early days with her.
She'll tell you that.
She's praised me.
She says, you knew my husband better than I did.
And I asked Ann Rutter that question.
And what were his, as you remember the table conversation or anything at home, what were his greatest joys and frustrations?
She said, I don't remember his ever bringing anything home.
That he would go back to the office and work.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah.
Or he wouldn't go home until late.
Like when we were having a session or something.
No, you're right.
He never took things home.
He never discussed it and never let it affect his family life at all.
In your days of working with the legislature, which legislators would you give gold stars to for their support of A&M and higher education?
Well, let me preface my remark by saying that when Mr. Rutter was active, he handled political matters himself, legislative matters almost entirely.
It was only when I had to substitute for him or something.
Locally, of course, Bill Moore was by far the king, the key to the whole thing.
And he carried the legislature in those days.
They didn't call him Bull of the Brazzers for any reason.
for no reason because he was rough and tough on them over there and got what he wanted through.
A number of the board members were very influential with the politicians.
little short guy that used to fight with Bill Moore that was in the legislature at that time.
He was from the Gulf Coast area.
Oh, uh, Babe Swartz.
Yeah, Babe Swartz, little short guy that I call him.
Reminded me of Lincoln.
Debater, Douglas, I guess.
Yeah, but in those days, a lot of the stuff was handled behind the scenes, and I was never much of a politician, and I never got involved with the politicians except at Mr.
Rudder's behest, because that was one thing that he handled and handled well.
He allowed me to run the campus and do the academics and see everything was going all right on the campus, but politics, he wanted to be involved.
See, I have a Civic Club speech I've made a number of times.
I call it...
Camelot on the Brazos, using the Kennedy family use of that term.
And I tell people that those of us that were here in the 60s and early 70s particularly, that we felt that things were happening.
that this place was going.
Oh, yeah, that's the thing that really stimulated me, kept me going, because we were putting in tremendous hours and working real hard.
It was trying, too, some of this stuff.
I'm sure it must have been.
But that's what kept me going, that I could see real progress happening.
And the fact that Mr. Rutter would almost give me carte blanche on anything academic or research or student-wise that I would recommend to him.
except initially about abolishing the Corps and stuff like that.
All right, do you remember any academic triumphs that cause you great pleasure to recall?
Well, I think initially when the board approved Mr.
Rudder's endorsement, the realignment or reorganization of A&M, which is essentially what it is today, with the exception of medicine.
We didn't have medicine at that time.
I don't know.
The real thing was that Mr. Rutter allowed me to work with the academic deans almost at will and to get things done.
And he would back me up, even though he might not know the background of what happened.
If he said Hall said it, you're damn well you're going to do it.
I shouldn't use that language.
No, no, no.
Now, the commencement ceremonies here to me have always been impressive.
Were they pretty similar when you started as the chief academic officer to what they are now?
Were they then shaking every hand, calling every name?
Yeah, every Aggie walked across the stage, his name was called.
I think I can remember that we did it several times in the early days.
There was no air conditioning.
When Eisenhower gave the commencement address, we had it out in the stadium or near the stadium.
Oh, yeah.
Those days I didn't even own a cap and gown.
I had to run it each time That's how I used to bitch about when I was a young sister professor to put that money out Later his I got to be chairman.
I bought finally bought a cap and got figured I was gonna have to Wear it every year two or three times a year.
I

i've always thought that's one of the traditions here that is a nice inclusive item that kind of makes it an aggie family in fact the parents usually came when they were looking forward to seeing their son's name called out and therefore when we ask them for their assistance

five years or fifty years later that positive last memory was uh... was so good that you say you have an eleven o'clock yeah i gotta go to through the dark let's uh... let's then terminate today okay and we'll resume uh... at another time of your convenience well almost any time
